structural_value_constraints_register.constraint: 21% Net Revenue Leakage (14% bookings growth - 7% revenue decline)
structural_value_constraints_register.why_severity: Mathematical proof of business model dysfunction. Implies churn + contraction rate of ~21% annually exceeding new customer acquisition at 14%. Affects entire $2,737M revenue base. Cannot be sustained - requires either eliminating 21% leakage (impossible without multi-year structural transformation) or accelerating bookings growth to 28%+ to offset (requires doubling sales investment). Neither financially viable with current constraints.
structural_value_constraints_register.what_breaks_if_touched: If attempt to reduce churn 21% â†’ <5%: Requires massive retention investment ($100-200M+ annually), building differentiation/lock-in (years + $50-100M), or implementing contractual lock-in (triggers 30-40% customer exit wave rejecting bait-and-switch). All paths financially impossible or counterproductive. If accept leakage: Revenue declines 5-10% annually compounding until financial distress (SG&A $709M becomes unsustainable as % of shrinking revenue).
open_unknowns: Actual NRR/GRR by segment to determine if leakage localized or systemic
Churn drivers by segment to identify if any are addressable vs structural

structural_value_constraints_register.why_severity: Affects $1,683M Public Cloud (61% of revenue). Hyperscalers capture 89.6% of customer value while Rackspace captures 10.4%. Partner credits (5-15%) constitute Rackspace infrastructure margin - modifiable unilaterally by hyperscalers. If credits reduced from 10% to 5%, Public Cloud margin falls from 10.4% to 5.4% (potentially loss-making after overhead). Rackspace has ZERO negotiating leverage (< 0.5% of hyperscaler revenue). Structural asymmetry cannot be eliminated without fundamentally different business model (owning infrastructure vs reselling).
structural_value_constraints_register.what_breaks_if_touched: If hyperscalers reduce partner credits: Public Cloud becomes unprofitable, must exit 61% of business. If attempt to pass credit reductions to customers: Triggers churn (customers go direct to hyperscaler). If exit hyperscaler partnerships: $1,683M revenue disappears immediately (cannot deliver Public Cloud without AWS/Azure/Google). Constraint is IRREVERSIBLE TRAP - business model requires partners who control economics.
open_unknowns: Actual hyperscaler partner agreement terms (credit rates, termination provisions, volume commitments)
Hyperscaler concentration (if 60-70% on primary, concentration risk compounds asymmetry)

structural_value_constraints_register.why_severity: Affects $1,055M Private Cloud (39% of revenue) providing 40-50% of operating income. Broadcom raised VMware prices 200-300%, estimated $100-210M value transfer from Rackspace to VMware. Private Cloud margin compressed from 38.6% to estimated 25-30% if absorbed, OR revenue decline accelerates if passed through. Cannot exit VMware without 20-30% customer loss (migration failure rate). Constraint threatens viability of most profitable segment.
structural_value_constraints_register.what_breaks_if_touched: If absorb VMware costs: Private Cloud operating margin drops from estimated 30-40% to 10-15%, OI contribution falls from $315-420M to $105-160M (loss of $210-260M profit = 50-60% of total OI). Business becomes unprofitable. If pass through costs: Customer churn accelerates from -13% to -20-30% YoY (death spiral). If exit VMware via customer migration: 20-30% customer loss = $210-315M revenue impact plus operational disruption. All paths destroy value.
open_unknowns: Actual VMware cost increase amount and timing
Private Cloud VMware exposure (% of segment using VMware vs alternatives)
Customer migration feasibility and expected loss rate

structural_value_constraints_register.constraint: SG&A Structural Inefficiency ($709M at 25.9% vs healthy 15-18%)
structural_value_constraints_register.why_severity: Overhead 25.9% of revenue vs healthy MSP benchmark 15-18%. Implies business needs $4-5B revenue (48-72% above current) to efficiently amortize $709M SG&A. Multi-entity fragmentation (Government isolation, UK Sovereign separation, jurisdictional requirements) prevents consolidation and economies of scale. SG&A flat as % despite revenue decline - NO OPERATING LEVERAGE. Structural constraint that cannot be resolved without exiting fragmented segments or selling business.
structural_value_constraints_register.what_breaks_if_touched: If reduce SG&A to match revenue ($400-500M target = 30-40% cut): Requires exiting entity operations (Government, UK Sovereign), massive headcount reductions (1,500-2,000 FTEs from 5,100), potentially delisting (eliminate public company overhead). All paths trigger operational collapse and customer exodus. If grow revenue to match SG&A ($4B target = 48% growth): Blocked by 21% net leakage and commoditization. Cannot achieve either scale or efficiency. TRAPPED.
open_unknowns: Detailed SG&A breakdown by function to identify reduction opportunities
Segment exit modeling - if exit SMB, what SG&A can be eliminated vs stranded?

structural_value_constraints_register.why_severity: Operating income concentrated in Private Cloud (40-50% of OI from 39% revenue) and Government (15-25% of OI from 10-15% revenue). Business depends on two segments for majority of profit. Within segments, estimated high customer concentration (top 10-15 customers 20-40% of segment revenue). Loss of either segment or top customers is existentially threatening. Creates unresolvable resource allocation conflict - cannot optimize for both profit (defend high-margin) AND revenue scale (grow low-margin) with limited resources.
structural_value_constraints_register.what_breaks_if_touched: If lose Private Cloud segment: Eliminate $315-420M OI (40-50% of total), remaining business has $1,682M revenue with $310-420M OI but $709M SG&A = operating margin -23% to -5% (deep losses). Financial collapse. If lose top 10-15 customers across high-margin segments: Estimated $410-685M revenue loss (15-25% of total), $100-200M OI impact (30-50% of total), business becomes marginally profitable or loss-making. Month-to-month billing means this can occur in 3-6 months.
open_unknowns: Actual customer concentration by segment (top 10/50/100 customer revenue %)
Customer identification (who are largest customers? what dependency characteristics?)

structural_value_constraints_register.constraint: Zero Contractual Lock-In + Fixed Cost Structure
structural_value_constraints_register.why_severity: Month-to-month billing universal eliminates contractual protection. Customers can exit with 30-day notice, no early termination fees. Meanwhile, massive fixed/semi-fixed costs ($709M SG&A, data centers, infrastructure) require revenue stability. Top 10-20 customers could exit in 3-6 months eliminating 25-40% of revenue while costs remain fixed. Creates MAXIMUM VULNERABILITY to rapid revenue loss.
structural_value_constraints_register.what_breaks_if_touched: If implement contractual lock-in (shift to annual/multi-year contracts with ETFs): Existing customers reject (30-40% estimated churn wave rather than accept new terms), new customers resist (competitors offering month-to-month gain advantage), enterprise customers demand price discounts for commitment (20-30% typical, destroying margins). Net result: churn wave offsets any stability benefit. Cannot reverse month-to-month without triggering exit wave. IRREVERSIBLE TRAP.
open_unknowns: Contract terms distribution - what % pure month-to-month vs committed spend vs multi-year?
Would customers accept contractual changes if offered incentives?

structural_value_constraints_register.constraint: Private Cloud Declining 13% YoY While Providing 40-50% OI
structural_value_constraints_register.why_severity: Most profitable segment (Private Cloud estimated 30-40% operating margin, 40-50% of total OI) declining FASTEST at 13% YoY while business UNDERINVESTS (CapEx down 25% from $181M to $136M). Actions contradict dependency - should be increasing investment to defend critical profit source, instead cutting investment. Indicates either management incompetence (doesn't understand dependency) or capitulation (given up on segment, harvesting).
structural_value_constraints_register.what_breaks_if_touched: If invest to defend ($170-395M annually for increased CapEx, VMware absorption, service quality): Consumes 40-125% of segment profit making segment unprofitable to defend. If harvest (continue underinvestment): Decline accelerates to -20-30% YoY, segment revenue falls to $700-850M over 2-3 years, OI contribution drops $105-125M (15-20% of total OI). If exit: Immediate loss of 40-50% of total OI, remaining business unprofitable. ALL PATHS LEAD TO DISTRESS. No viable resolution.
open_unknowns: Management strategic plan for Private Cloud - defend, harvest, or exit?
Private Cloud customer economics - which customers driving decline? Can any be retained?

structural_value_constraints_register.why_severity: Government entity isolation (FedRAMP requirement), UK Sovereign architectural separation (sovereignty requirement), jurisdictional entities (regulatory requirements) prevent consolidation. Creates duplicate overhead (finance, HR, legal, compliance per entity), prevents sales/operations consolidation, blocks economies of scale. Fragmentation is LEGALLY/REGULATORILY MANDATED - cannot be eliminated without exiting segments or losing authorizations. Contributes to SG&A inefficiency (25.9% vs 15-18% benchmark).
structural_value_constraints_register.what_breaks_if_touched: If consolidate Government entity: FedRAMP authorization LOST, $270-410M revenue eliminated, $70-145M OI impact (15-25% of total). If consolidate UK Sovereign: Architectural isolation BREACHED, UK government/regulated customers lost, segment failure, $5-15M+ investment sunk cost. If exit fragmented segments to simplify: Lose revenue and profit, but SG&A doesn't reduce proportionally (stranded overhead). Fragmentation cannot be resolved without destroying business or segments.
open_unknowns: Quantified cost of fragmentation - how much SG&A is duplicate overhead vs necessary?
Could entities be consolidated post-acquisition if acquirer already has similar entities?
